TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: ti Pułałułałuyan katua qaḍis (Kułałau village, p.228)

S.TRANSL: There was Pułałułałuyan Vavuluvulungan.

S.FORM: izua ti Tjukutjuku a Kaḍangiangian i qinałan a mamaw.
izoa ti Tjokotjoko a Kadrangiangian i qinaljan a mamaw.
S.TRANSL: There was Tjukutjuku Kaḍangiangian in the same village.

S.FORM: izua kuku ni Pułałułałuyan a qaḍis.
izoa koko ni Poljaljoljaljoyan a qadris.
S.TRANSL: Pułałułałuyan had a pet hawk.

S.FORM: nu kisudju ti Pułałułałuyan a sema Kaḍangiangian, avanu qaqivuin azua qaḍis.
no kisodjo ti Poljaljoljaljoyan a sema Kadrangiangian, avano qaqivoin azoa qadris.
S.TRANSL: When Pułałułałuyan went courting to the Kaḍangiangian house, he called the hawk to go along.
On the way there was a field at Djałalu.

S.FORM: manu vaik tia Pułałułałuyan katua qaḍis.
mano vaik tia Poljaljoljaljoyan katoa qadris.
S.TRANSL: Pułałułałuyan and the hawk went off.

S.FORM: manu rinaung nua qała a se Łinasalas.
mano rinaong noa qalja a se Ljinasalas.
S.TRANSL: Enemies from Łinasalas lay in ambush.

S.FORM: manu kemłang a qaḍis tu izua qała.
mano kemljang a qadris to izoa qalja.
S.TRANSL: The hawk knew there were enemies there.
“Come on, let’s go back, Pułałułałuyan; there are enemies here.”
“Never mind,” said Pułałałułuyan.

S.FORM: manu djemałun tua quma, sa kuangi nua qała ti Pułałułałuyan; manu matsay.
mano djemaljon toa qoma, sa koangi noa qalja ti Poljaljoljaljoyan; mano macay.
S.TRANSL: They reached the field, and Pułałułałuyan was shot by the enemies, and died.

S.FORM: "'ai anga ti kaka i Pułałułałuyan," aya a kuku a qaḍis.
"'ai anga ti kaka i Poljaljoljaljoyan," aya a koko a qadris.
S.TRANSL: “Oh poor brother Pułałułałuyan!” said the pet hawk.
“What can I do to bring my brother back to life?”
Well he came back to life.
People came to the rescue.
“What’s all the fuss about?” said Pułałułałuyan.
“We thought you were dead.”
“Dead indeed, a tough male like me!
Come on, let’s just go home.”
When he got home,
his mother was crying.
“Don’t cry, mother, I’m still alive.
It’s nothing to a male like me.”
That’s the end of the story.
